claim: Bell's theorem demonstrated that quantum mechanics predicts stronger statistical correlations in measurements of entangled particles than any local realistic theory could.

Experiments starting with John Clauser and Alain Aspect in the 1970s and 1980s confirmed quantum predictions by violating Bell inequalities, solidifying entanglement as a real and non-local feature of nature.
Bell's theorem challenged the principle of locality, which states that an object can be influenced only by its immediate surroundings.
The discovery has profound implications for quantum technologies, including quantum computing and quantum cryptography.
The demise of local realism has made a lot of people very angry and has been widely regarded as a bad move.
